# Phonomorphological anticipation

## Central Swedish

Low tone + singular: _fisken_ 'fish<sub>[SG]</sub>'     
High tone + plural: _fiskar_ 'fish<sub>[PL]</sub>' <font size="-1">     
(Roll et al., 2010)</font>

## Spanish
First syllable stressed + present: _canta_ 's/he sings'     
First syllable unstressed + preterite: _cantó_ 's/he sang' <font size="-1">     
(Sagarra & Casillas, 2018)</font>

# Our study

## Does L1 transfer affect English and Mandarin Chinese speakers' ability to make stress-tense suffix predictions in L2 Spanish? If so, how?

## Does L2 use affect English and Mandarin Chinese speakers' ability to make stress-tense suffix predictions in L2 Spanish? If so, how?

--
- English faster and more likely to predict than Chinese speakers because of similarity
- More use will contribute to faster and likelier prediction

---

# Our study

Participants:
- 30 Spanish monolinguals
- 65 English speakers (L2 Spanish intermediate or above)
- 64 Mandarin Chinese speakers (L2 Spanish intermediate or above)

Materials:
- Proficiency test
- Language history questionnaire
- Visual world paradigm (eye-tracking)

# Our study

Participants:
- 30 Spanish monolinguals
- 65 English speakers (L2 Spanish intermediate or above)
- 64 Mandarin Chinese speakers (L2 Spanish intermediate or above)

Materials:
- Proficiency test
- Language history questionnaire
- Visual world paradigm (eye-tracking)

Analysis:
- Growth Curve Analysis <font size="-1">(Mirman, 2014)</font>

```{r eval=FALSE}
eLog ~ 1 + (ot1 + ot2 + ot3) + l1_sum + ot:l1_sum +
    condition_sum + ot1:condition_sum + ot2:condition_sum + 
    use_z + ot1:use_z + ot2:use_z + l1_sum:condition_sum:use_z +
    ot1:l1_sum:condition_sum:use_z + ot2:l1_sum:condition_sum:use_z +
    ot3:l1_sum:condition_sum:use_z +
    (1 + condition_sum + ot1 + ot2 + ot3 | participant) +
    (1 + ot1 + ot2 + ot3 | target)
```

# Results

.center[
```{r, include=TRUE, echo=FALSE, out.width="90%"}
include_graphics("./figs/stress/gca/use_l1.png", dpi = 150)
```
]

???
L2 use x ot1: Greater L2 use yielded a steeper rise, indicating that both learner groups predicted faster with greater the L2 use. 

Interaction between L1, stress, and L2 use in the cubic term, indicating that, in Mandarin learners, greater L2 use yielded a steeper and more closed curve in paroxytones. In other words, greater L2 use made English learners predict oxytones later but faster, and greater L2 use made Mandarin predict paroxytones later but faster.

# Discussion

- L1 cross-linguistic influence interacts with other factors
  - Farther away > less blocking vs. black and white <font size="-1">(Gosselke et al., 2018)</font></br>
  - Present tense influenced for:
      1. Stress pattern not as typical <font size="-1">(Li, 1982)</font>
      2. Tone 4 (falling) most typical <font size="-1">(Duanmu, 2011)</font>
